37147.title: Mastaba
37147.inscription: inscribed, signed and dated in pencil, C.L.: 34/70 Mastaba Rosenquist 1971
rights: © Licensed by VAGA, New York, NY

extended_text.content:
Rosenquist was excited and motivated by the bombardment of visual stimuli that the average American received daily from television and advertising.

Garbage dumps, the pyramids of American consumer society, inspired this print and its title-the mastaba being the precursor of the pyramids of Egypt.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

10117.title: beaded bag
10117.provenance: (Sotheby-Parke Bernet, Los Angeles); purchased by the Indianapolis Museum of Art (1976).

extended_text.content: Plains beadwork is often identified by the “lazy stitch” which strings several beads on one stitch and results in a more rigid pattern. Crow women created block designs in dark blue, green, yellow, light blue and pink. Although more time consuming, their couched stitching of long beaded strands allowed for more flexible designs.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

10117.exhibit_history:
Art of the Americas: Two Thousand Years of Native American Creativity
April 11-June 27, 1999

10113.title: beaded pouch
10113.provenance: (Sotheby-Parke Bernet, Los Angeles, California); purchased by the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1976.

24655.title: hexagonal beaded pouch with heart design
24655.creation_notes: origin: Quebec or Ontario if Canadian - Christian Feest, Mellon curator of Native American Art (2015)
24655.provenance:
Collection of Madame Ernestine Schumann-Heink [1861 - 1936] {1}; (Sotheby Parke Bernet, Inc, New York); purchased by the Indianapolis Museum of Art 1976.

{1} Ernestine Shumann-Heink nee Rossler was a Bohemian born opera contralto and is the inspiration for the buxom opera singer trope in American popular culture.  She was forced to return to the stage after losing her fortune in the 1929 stock market crash, and was forcued to continue preforming until 1932
24655.dimensions:
7-1/4 x 7 x 1/2 in. (without handle)
10-1/4 x 7 x 1/2 in. (with handle)

extended_text.content:
The form of this bag is derived from European examples.

By the 1700s American Indian artists in the East and Midwest had begun to decorate imported European cloth, rather than animal skin, for items of dress.

The intention of beaded dress items is to beautify and enhance an owner's status.

American Indian beadwork, in general, is decorative rather than symbolic, and most designs are geometric and floral.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

24655.current_location: Michael and Patricia McCrory & Richard and Rebecca Feldman Gallery (K214)

18770.title: blanket
18770.creation_notes: Place of Creation = Arizona OR New Mexico.
18770.description: Wool Tapestry Weave, cream, beige, dark brown, light brown, red
18770.credit_line: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. J. Irwin Miller
18770.provenance:
Mrs. J. Irwin Miller [1917-2008] {1} , Columbus, Indiana; donated to Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1987

{1} Xenia Simons Miller

extended_text.content:
This Navajo rug is a variation of Ganado-style rugs. Most of the modern or post-1940 Ganado rugs have large central medallion motifs; sometimes two or three diamonds are featured in the center. The colors in these rugs are camel-beige, grey, white, black, and deep red; the last two colors were dyed with synthetic dyes.

This rug, however, is an interesting variation of its type. The central stepped diamond has been divided in half and placed to the sides. The two vertical borders are placed in the middle, changing the traditional design and breaking the rules of border and medallion motifs known to appear in this type of rug. Four stepped arrows are depicted in the corners, and the Spider Woman, a Navajo deity, is depicted four times in the middle section. This mythical figure, who according to legend taught the Navajo the art of weaving, is formed by a cross with square blocks at the end of each arm.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

18770.exhibit_history: FOR EXHIBITIONS AND ROTATIONS DISPLAYED ON SITE AT THE IMA OR ON TOUR BY THE IMA, SEE THE EVENTS TAB.

22015.title: berry spoon with raven crest design
22015.creation_notes: Collected in Alaska by Albert P. Niblack in 1885-1886, per Christian Feest, 2014-2015 Mellon Curator of Native American Art
22015.description: would have been used with a rod for paddling
22015.provenance:
Likely collected Vice Admiral Albert P. Niblack [1859-1929] {1}, Indianapolis, Indiana; Eliza Niblack [1864-1930] {2}, Indianapolis; given to the John Herron Art Institute, now the Indianapolis Museum of Art, in 1930.

{1} Albert P. Niblack surveyed Alaska between 1885-1886 among the Kaigani Haida in southeastern Alaska
{2} Eliza Niblack died in Brooklyn, New York in June 1930

12530.title: ceremonial feast ladle with representations of killer whale, bear, and medicine man
12530.creation_notes: Collected in Alaska by Albert P. Niblack in 1885-1886 per Christian Feest, 2014-2015 Mellon Curator of Native American Art
12530.credit_line: Gift of Vice Admiral Albert Parker Niblack

extended_text.content:
The surface of this feast ladle is carved with various images, the most prominent of which is a killer whale.

The carving on this feast ladle demonstrates the tendency of artists of this region to fill almost all available surfaces with images.

Sheep and goat horn is softened with steamed or boiled water, and shaped in a mold to create a proper shape for ladles.

Ladles are used to serve fish oil to guests during feasts.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

12530.current_location: Michael and Patricia McCrory & Richard and Rebecca Feldman Gallery (K214)

{1} Leon Hugh 'Cozy' McSparron along with his wife Inja McSparron encourged local Navajo weavers to create better quality weaving using vegetable dyes to sell to tourists.  He was close friends with Dr. Thomas Noble, Jr. of Indianapolis 
{2} John Noble is the son of Dr. Thomas Benjamin Noble, Jr. (IMA historical file 1983.118)
{3} Patricia Noble is the daughter of Thomas Benjamin Noble, Jr. and sister of John Noble (IMA historical file 1983.118)

63424.title: swim suit
63424.description:
An orange and purple swimsuit with an off-white lining.  The suit is made of a wool and synthetic blend knit fabric, lined with a synthetic knit fabric.  The back, sides and halter straps of the suit are in purple knit, the front panel is in orange knit.  The halter strap fastens behind the neck with three, decorative, brass hook fasteners.  The suit is cut with very short legs which are gathered with elastic.
This suit was probably a manufacturer's sample.  The suit still has two original paper labels indicated the fiber content, machine operator's number, size, and model number.
An orange and purple swimsuit with an off-white lining.  The suit is made of a wool and synthetic blend knit fabric, lined with a synthetic knit fabric.  The back, sides and halter straps of the suit are in purple knit, the front panel is in orange knit.  The halter strap fastens behind the neck with three, decorative, brass hook fasteners.  The suit is cut with very short legs which are gathered with elastic. 20% wool, 80% Orlon
63424.dimensions:
length: 31 in
width: 14 in
depth: 1 in

16365.description: A = robe, B = teddy (based on past records). White/cream colored chiffon and satin appliquéd with  French lace, seed pearls, crystals.  Winner of the FEMME Award, 1988.

36141.title: day ensemble
36141.title_notes: A) dress B) cardigan C) belt
36141.description: day ensemble, short halter neck dress, long cardigan coat, string belt
36141.provenance: David W. Campbell, New York, New York (Stan Weaver, New York, New York); given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1985.
36141.dimensions:
A) dress: length 50-1/2 in.
B) cardigan: length 36-3/4 in.
B) belt: length 37-1/4 in.

extended_text.content:
Halston had an incredible sense of color, and it is said that he never had enough colors to work with. Lilac, which was never popular, was made desirable because the shade he introduced was so elegant.

The cardigan jacket has a jewel neckline with long, slender sleeves. The mother-of-pearl buttons were dyed to match and a narrow self-tie belt is worn with it.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

36141.exhibit_history:
Simply Halston
Paul Fashion Arts Gallery, IMA
April 13, 2008 - January 4, 2009

11358.title: tunic and pants
11358.description: fluted sleeves, bias cut, wide width pants, machine embroidered with sequins
11358.credit_line: Gift of Mrs. Gerald L. Herzfeld
11358.provenance: Mrs. Gerald L. (Geraldine) Herzfeld,  (d. 2009) New York, New York; through (Stan Weaver, New York, New York; given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art in 1985.
11358.dimensions:
A) tunic: 31 1/2 in. (length)
B) pants: 43 in. (length)

extended_text.content: Halston debuted his concept for “pajama dressing,” a contemporary version of the popular 1930s style, in his first collection of 1968. The approach was simple, the line uncomplicated, and the fabric interesting and unexpected. Pajama-like in fashion and encrusted with sequins, this two-piece ensemble consists of a tunic with fluted raglan sleeves and straight widelegged trousers. It allows the wearer to be comfortable while promoting an air of chic sophistication.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

11358.exhibit_history: "An American Legacy; Norell, Blass, Halston & Sprouse," Paul Fashion Arts Gallery, Indianapolis Museum of Art, Indianapolis, Indiana, 05/04/2012-01/27/2013  |

3207.title: jumpsuit
3207.title_notes: A) cape B) jumpsuit C) belt
3207.description: a) wide leg jumpsuit, b) one piece construction cape (poncho), c) tie (belt)
3207.provenance: Jane B. Holzer, New York; through (Stan Weaver, New York): given to the Indianapolis Museum of Art (1986).
3207.dimensions:
A) cape:
B) jumpsuit:
C) belt:

extended_text.content: Presented in Halston’s earliest collections, the sexy and easy-to-wear jumpsuit became a signature look. Halston transformed the jumpsuit into glamorous, comfortable evening wear by constructing many different versions using various luxe fabrics, thus changing the way people thought about a style formerly associated with auto mechanics and skiers. This formfitting jumpsuit with bell-bottom pant legs and a self-tie belt is made from exquisite cashmere, a favorite fabric of the designer’s since early adulthood.
extended_text.title: Gallery Label

3207.exhibit_history:
An American Legacy; Norell, Blass, Halston & Sprouse
Paul Textile and Fashion Arts galleries, IMA
May 4, 2012 - January 27, 2013
